_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source [40 CFR 68.155(a)]:
The facility is committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our accidental release prevention program that encompasses design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training. Engineering controls are in place to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. This site is a non-responding facility for releases of the RMP-listed chemicals, so the site utilizes an Emergency Action Plan.

The stationary source and regulated substances handled [40 CFR 68.155(b)]:
The facility produces and collects biogas in digesters from cow manure that collect manure and treats the biogas to produce renewable natural gas (RNG). 

Due to the nature of biogas (e.g., significant presence of non-volatile components), the facility has a low potential for explosion consistent with naturally occurring hydrocarbon mixtures, which are exempt from RMP regulations. The natural gas contains methane, which is a flammable RMP-regulated chemical.  The potential exists for methane to be present at the site in quantities above the RMP threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds. The RNG produced from biogas is injected into a pipeline. The RNG contains methane, which is a flammable RMP-regulated chemical. The digesters holding the biogas can contain greater than 10,000 pounds of RNG. Although there are small amounts of H2S and ammonia associated with the process, there are no RMP-regulated toxic chemicals stored above threshold quantities on site. The site has 2 fulltime employees onsite; the operators only go to the site to complete regular maintenance and operations when they receive RNG.

The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps [40 CFR 68.155(c)]:
The facility has a program in place to comply with the provisions of the accidental release prevention regulations under 40 CFR Pa

rt 68. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the existing release prevention program.

Process Safety Information [40 CFR Part 68.65]
The facility maintains a record of process safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.

Process Hazard Analysis [40 CFR Part 68.67]
Analyses ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified and controlled efficiently. The methodology used to carry out these analyses is HAZOP. The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of at least 5 years. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Written Operating Procedures [40 CFR Part 68.69]
To ensure safe operations, the facility maintains detailed written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations and normal shutdown. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.

Employee Training [40 CFR Part 68.71]
The facility has a training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating plant processes are competent in the applicable operating procedures. Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.

Mechanical Integrity [40 CFR Part 68.73]
The facility carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations. Inspected process equipment includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, pressure relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps. Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed. Any eq

uipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Management of Change [MOC] [40 CFR Part 68.75]
Written procedures are in place at the site to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures. Facility operators or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification(s).

Pre-Startup Safety Review [PSSR] [40 CFR Part 68.77]
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and modifications to existing processes are conducted routinely at the facility. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating, and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Compliance Audits [40 CFR Part 68.79]
The facility conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the US EPA RMP and OSHA PSM regulations are being implemented. These audits are conducted at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a prompt manner.

Incident Investigation [40 CFR Part 68.81]
The facility promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum period of 5 years.

Employee Participation [40 CFR Part 68.83]
The facility believes that Process Safety Management and accident prevention is a team effort. Employees are encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP and PSM rules, including information res

ulting from Process Hazard Analyses in particular.

Hot Work Permit [40 CFR Part 68.85]
The facility has a hot work program that requires issuance of a hot work permit for hot work operations conducted on or near the covered process. 

Contractor Safety Program [40 CFR Part 68.87] 
The facility occasionally hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is carried out. The site has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards associated with the contractor's work and the corresponding processes. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.

The five-year accident history [40 CFR 68.155(d)]:
The facility is a new process and has therefore had no accidents.

The emergency response program [40 CFR 68.155(e)]:
In the event of an incident, the facility has systems in place to respond quickly. Processes can be shut down on an emergency basis and the facility has a plan in place for evacuations, adequate first aid, and medical treatment and notification of local emergency response agencies. The facility is a non-responding facility and relies on Seward County Fire & EMS to respond to chemical releases.

Planned changes to improve safety [40 CFR 68.155(f)]:
Since the site is a new process, it is continually ensuring the implementation of the prevention program, including the closure of the most recent PHA recommendations.

The facility has completed this report to provide the public with information about our activities at this facility.  We believe that, due to the many controls instituted to maintain a safe operation and our commitment to continuous improvement, an incident affecting our employees, or the surrounding area is unlikely to occur.
